title: How to Relieve Breast Pain After Abortion

steps.title: Use heat and cold treatments to reduce tenderness.
steps.content: Use heat and cold treatments to reduce tenderness . Ice packs can help reduce swelling and inflammation which can alleviate your pain. Hot compresses, warm baths or heating pads can also help. Alternating between hot and cold treatments, with 20-minute breaks in between, can help manage your pain. [1] X Research source Cool cabbage leaves are also a traditional folk remedy for breast tenderness and there have been some modern studies to support this. [2] X Trustworthy Source PubMed Central Journal archive from the U.S. National Institutes of Health Go to source For heat or ice treatments, the general recommendation is 20 minutes on, followed by a 20-minute break. [3] X Trustworthy Source Cleveland Clinic Educational website from one of the world's leading hospitals Go to source

steps.title: Use an NSAID topical cream for pain relief.
steps.content: Use an NSAID topical cream for pain relief. Check with your physician and follow your aftercare instructions when making decisions about pain relieving drugs. Topical use of non-steroidal anti-inflammatory creams are very effective in treating breast pain and can be prescribed for you by a doctor or nurse practitioner. [4] X Trustworthy Source PubMed Central Journal archive from the U.S. National Institutes of Health Go to source Oral use of NSAIDs has not been demonstrated to help alleviate breast pain, but they are anti-inflammatories so some women may find relief using over-the-counter ibuprofen or naproxen. [5] X Trustworthy Source American Academy of Family Physicians Organization devoted to improving the health of patients, families, and communities Go to source Diclofenac, an NSAID topical, is very effective in relieving breast pain. [6] X Trustworthy Source PubMed Central Journal archive from the U.S. National Institutes of Health Go to source This requires a prescription to obtain, so follow the instructions on its use as provided by your pharmacist. [7] X Trustworthy Source Mayo Clinic Educational website from one of the world's leading hospitals Go to source If taking naproxen orally, dosage is 500mg at first, then 250mg every 6 to 8 hours as required. [8] X Trustworthy Source National Health Service (UK) Public healthcare system of the UK Go to source Dosage for oral ibuprofen for mild to moderate pain is 400mg every 4 to 6 hours as needed. [9] X Trustworthy Source Mayo Clinic Educational website from one of the world's leading hospitals Go to source

steps.title: Wear a well-fitted cotton bra to support your breasts.
steps.content: Wear a well-fitted cotton bra to support your breasts. Look for a bra with no underwire that does not push your breasts against your chest, like an encapsulation-style sports bra that lifts and separates. [10] X Trustworthy Source National Health Service (UK) Public healthcare system of the UK Go to source Check your size by measuring your chest at the bottom of your breasts while wearing your bra. If you get an odd number, add 5 inches (13 cm). If it's even, add 4 inches (10 cm). That is your band size. Find your cup size by measuring around the widest part of your chest. Subtract your two measurements and use the following size guide: [11] X Research source Less than 1 inch (2.5 cm) is aa AA 1 inch (2.5 cm) is an A 2 inches (5.1 cm) is a B 3 inches (7.6 cm) is a C 4 inches (10 cm) is a D 5 inches (13 cm) is a DD

steps.title: Practice relaxation therapy to reduce pain-related anxiety.
steps.content: Practice relaxation therapy to reduce pain-related anxiety. [12] X Trustworthy Source National Cancer Institute An agency in the National Institutes of Health focused on cancer research and patient support Go to source Refocus your mind away from emotional and physical pain to ease your discomfort and calm your thoughts. Relax in a comfortable position in a calm and quiet place. Close your eyes and breathe deeply and regularly. Using guided imagery, focus your thoughts on pleasant, happy images as you breathe. Relax tense muscles as you continue to breathe deeply. [13] X Trustworthy Source Mayo Clinic Educational website from one of the world's leading hospitals Go to source Practice relaxation therapy by yourself, or with the help of a trained therapist. [14] X Research source

steps.title: Switch to a high-fiber diet.
steps.content: Switch to a high-fiber diet. Eating a diet that is low in animal fats and high in whole grains, vegetables and beans, will help your body breakdown the additional estrogen your it has been producing. The more quickly your body can metabolize this excess estrogen, the sooner your breast tenderness will subside. [15] X Research source Green peas, broccoli, oatmeal, quinoa, lentils and black beans are good examples of foods to include in a high-fiber diet. [16] X Trustworthy Source Mayo Clinic Educational website from one of the world's leading hospitals Go to source A low-carb, high-fiber diet is particularly effective, as it is largely plant-based and rich in colorful vegetables. The more colorful your plate, the better! Whole grains like quinoa are also excellent options.

steps.title: Eat foods that are high in vitamin C, calcium, magnesium and B vitamins.
steps.content: Eat foods that are high in vitamin C, calcium, magnesium and B vitamins. These particular vitamins help your body regulate the hormone, prolactin, which is the chemical your body produces during pregnancy to prepare your breasts for lactation. By supporting the regulation of this hormone through your diet, you can help your body regain its regular balance. [17] X Research source Oranges and other citrus fruits are great sources of vitamin C. [18] X Research source You can find calcium in dairy products and leafy green vegetables like kale. [19] X Research source Magnesium-rich foods include options like dark chocolate, almonds and edamame (soy beans), can further aid in balancing hormones and reducing discomfort. [20] X Trustworthy Source Cleveland Clinic Educational website from one of the world's leading hospitals Go to source

steps.title: Take a vitamin E supplement for two weeks.
steps.content: Take a vitamin E supplement for two weeks. Studies on the benefits of vitamin E supplements are not conclusive, but some women find relief when used for the short term. [21] X Trustworthy Source PubMed Central Journal archive from the U.S. National Institutes of Health Go to source Talk to your doctor before taking a supplement. [22] X Trustworthy Source Cleveland Clinic Educational website from one of the world's leading hospitals Go to source The dose considered safe for supplementation is 150-200 IUI. [23] X Trustworthy Source Harvard Medical School Harvard Medical School's Educational Site for the Public Go to source 1 IUI is equal to 0.45mg of synthetic vitamin E, or alpha-tocopheral, so when taking supplements do not exceed 67.5-90mg of vitamin E per day. [24] X Research source Instead of supplements, you can include foods naturally high in these vitamins. Vitamin E is found in almonds, peanuts, avocados, and spinach, among others. [25] X Research source If you continue to experience breast pain after 2 weeks, check with your healthcare provider.

steps.title: Consume Omega-3 fatty acids.
steps.content: Consume Omega-3 fatty acids. Although the benefits of this have not held up in rigorous scientific studies, some women may find breast pain relief from incorporating plenty of Omega-3 fatty acids through diet or supplementation. [26] X Trustworthy Source Cleveland Clinic Educational website from one of the world's leading hospitals Go to source Check with your physician before taking a supplement as ingesting high levels of these compounds can interfere with some medications, like anti-coagulants. Two types of Omega-3 are recommended, EPA and DHA, at a daily intake of 250mg each. [27] X Research source Omega-3 fatty acids can be found in fish, flaxseed, fortified dairy products (check the label), and leafy greens like kale, brussel sprouts and spinach.

steps.title: Take primrose oil supplements for an alternative approach.
steps.content: Take primrose oil supplements for an alternative approach. Like many other supplements, scientific evidence has not been able to support the efficacy of primrose oil for breast pain issues. [28] X Research source However, it is generally considered to be a relatively safe and long-standing folk remedy that many women have found works for them. Do not take evening primrose if you have a bleeding disorder, epilepsy, seizures or if you are planning to have surgery in the next two weeks. Always discuss supplements with your doctor before taking anything new. [29] X Trustworthy Source Mayo Clinic Educational website from one of the world's leading hospitals Go to source Look for this supplement in most drug stores or online.

steps.title: Avoid caffeine and nicotine to minimize discomfort.
steps.content: Avoid caffeine and nicotine to minimize discomfort. Although not conclusive, some studies suggest that caffeine and nicotine can contribute to breast pain. Some women find that reducing or stopping their consumption of these compounds from coffee, tea, soda and, in the case of nicotine, tobacco products, does provide some relief. [30] X Trustworthy Source Cleveland Clinic Educational website from one of the world's leading hospitals Go to source

steps.title: Reduce sodium intake to reduce swelling.
steps.content: Reduce sodium intake to reduce swelling. Eating a high-salt diet can cause your body to retain water, adding to swelling in your already painful breast tissue. Limit your salt intake by avoiding highly processed foods, fast food, and table salt for a couple of weeks while your body adjusts. [31] X Trustworthy Source Cleveland Clinic Educational website from one of the world's leading hospitals Go to source Consider alternative flavor-enhancers beyond table salt when cooking at home. Try garlic powder, dried onion, and chili powder. [32] X Trustworthy Source University of California San Francisco Health Center Research hospital associated with UCSF, a leading medical university, providing innovative patient care and public health resources Go to source
